name: Cauldron of the Dagda
shortDescription: Inexhaustible cauldron of abundance that never empties and from which no one leaves unsatisfied
fullDescription: The Cauldron of the Dagda (Irish: Coire Ansic) is one of the Four Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann, brought from the mythical city of Murias. This magical vessel contained an endless supply of food and drink, ensuring that no one ever went away hungry. It represents the principle of divine abundance and the nurturing aspect of sovereignty.

mythologyContexts.usage: Symbol of divine kingship and sovereignty, used to feed the people and demonstrate the king's ability to provide abundance. Also associated with resurrection and renewal

textReferences.context: Lists the Cauldron as one of the Four Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann

textReferences.passage: The Second Battle of Mag Tuired
textReferences.context: The Dagda's cauldron provides sustenance for the gods

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents abundance, hospitality, and the life-giving power of the divine. The inexhaustible nature symbolizes the infinite generosity of the gods and the ideal of sovereignty as service to the people. Also connected to the womb and feminine creative power.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The cauldron motif is central to Celtic mythology, appearing in various forms (Cauldron of Rebirth in Welsh tradition, the Grail in Arthurian legend). It represents the Celtic value of hospitality and the sacred duty of rulers to provide for their people.

sources.passage: The Second Battle of Mag Tuired

linguistic.originalScript: Old Irish: Coire Ansic (Cauldron of Plenty), Undry

etymology.derivation: From Old Irish coire (cauldron, kettle) + ansic (protection, preservation). Proto-Celtic *koryos (cauldron). Undry from Irish un- (not) + dry (ending), meaning never-ending. Cauldron associated with Dagda, god of abundance

cognates.meaning: cauldron (cf. Pair Dadeni - Cauldron of Rebirth)
